articles.headline: The New Workplace Is Agile, and Nonstop. Can You Keep Up?
articles.snippet: Cloud computing and agile computing have proved to be a strong combination. Work/life balance may give way to work/life mix.
articles.abstract: Cloud computing and agile computing have proved to be a strong combination. Work/life balance may give way to work/life mix.
articles.lead_paragraph: Whether you like it or not, your boss may want you to start acting more like a programmer.

articles.headline: Inside a Fake News Sausage Factory: ‘This Is All About Income’
articles.snippet: A computer science student in a former Soviet republic found there was money to be made in mixing real and made-up stories, as long as they were pro-Trump.
articles.abstract: A computer science student in a former Soviet republic found there was money to be made in mixing real and made-up stories, as long as they were pro-Trump.
articles.lead_paragraph: TBILISI, Georgia — Jobless and with graduation looming, a computer science student at the premier university in the nation of Georgia decided early this year that money could be made from America’s voracious appetite for passionately partisan political news. He set up a website, posted gushing stories about Hillary Clinton and waited for ad sales to soar.
articles.byline: By Andrew Higgins, Mike McIntire and Gabriel J.x. Dance

articles.headline: Shenzhen Connect Offers Chinese Stocks. Will the World Buy?
articles.snippet: Global investors will be able to tap China’s tech-heavy Shenzhen market, but many investors worry about last year’s crash and government interference.
articles.abstract: Global investors will be able to tap China’s tech-heavy Shenzhen market, but many investors worry about last year’s crash and government interference.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Global investors in two weeks will get direct access for the first time to the stock market in the Chinese city of Shenzhen, giving them a chance to bet on a tech-heavy clutch of private companies on an exchange sometimes called China’s Nasdaq.

articles.headline: A Candidate Rises on Vows to Control Islam and Immigration. This Time in France.
articles.snippet: François Fillon’s promises to limit immigration and protect conservative values in France have helped propel him to the front of the presidential field.
articles.abstract: François Fillon’s promises to limit immigration and protect conservative values in France have helped propel him to the front of the presidential field.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHASSIEU, France — A patriotic sea of supporters, waving red, white and blue flags, greeted the newly ascendant presidential hopeful François Fillon this week at a soulless conference center in this suburb of Lyon.

articles.headline: A Filmmaker’s Belief in Himself Pays Off
articles.snippet: Determined to gain critical respect, Shawn Levy, director of family comedies, built the production company behind the hit film “Arrival.”
articles.abstract: Determined to gain critical respect, Shawn Levy, director of family comedies, built the production company behind the hit film “Arrival.”
articles.lead_paragraph: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif. — Shawn Levy quickly made a name for himself in Hollywood. Maybe too quickly.

articles.headline: Stalking Black Friday Bargains
articles.snippet: Even as more people shop online, millions, including two sisters from New York and New Jersey, still rely on Black Friday discounts in stores.
articles.abstract: Even as more people shop online, millions, including two sisters from New York and New Jersey, still rely on Black Friday discounts in stores.
articles.lead_paragraph: RIVERDALE, N.J. — With a baby strapped to her front, a knapsack on her back and a Donald Duck coffee mug in one hand, Christi Mulder arrived at the Target here, about 30 miles northwest of Manhattan, early Friday morning. She and her sister, Erica Renaud, who brought her 7-week-old son, were on the hunt for holiday gifts for the 11 children they have between them.

articles.headline: U.S. Officials Defend Integrity of Vote, Despite Hacking Fears
articles.snippet: Some opponents of Donald J. Trump are seeking recounts in Wisconsin, Michigan and Pennsylvania, states where his margin of victory was extremely thin.
articles.abstract: Some opponents of Donald J. Trump are seeking recounts in Wisconsin, Michigan and Pennsylvania, states where his margin of victory was extremely thin.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration said on Friday that despite Russian attempts to undermine the presidential election, it has concluded that the results “accurately reflect the will of the American people.”

articles.headline: ‘Vulture’ or ‘Phoenix’? Wilbur Ross, Risk-Taker, Is Eyed for Commerce Post
articles.snippet: President-elect Donald J. Trump is turning not to a cautious corporate chieftain, but to somebody usually considered either a hero or a villain.
articles.abstract: President-elect Donald J. Trump is turning not to a cautious corporate chieftain, but to somebody usually considered either a hero or a villain.
articles.lead_paragraph: Wilbur L. Ross, the billionaire investor expected to be nominated as the next commerce secretary, has made his fortune through the tricky business of buying deeply troubled companies.

articles.headline: Fidel Castro, Cuban Revolutionary Who Defied U.S., Dies at 90
articles.snippet: Mr. Castro brought the Cold War to the Western Hemisphere, bedeviled 11 American presidents and briefly pushed the world to the brink of nuclear war.
articles.abstract: Mr. Castro brought the Cold War to the Western Hemisphere, bedeviled 11 American presidents and briefly pushed the world to the brink of nuclear war.
articles.lead_paragraph: Fidel Castro, the fiery apostle of revolution who brought the Cold War to the Western Hemisphere in 1959 and then defied the United States for nearly half a century as Cuba’s maximum leader, bedeviling 11 American presidents and briefly pushing the world to the brink of nuclear war, died on Friday. He was 90.

articles.headline: In Havana, Castro’s Death Lays Bare a Generation Gap
articles.snippet: In hearing about Fidel Castro’s death, many older Cubans went into mourning, but younger people were generally indifferent.
articles.abstract: In hearing about Fidel Castro’s death, many older Cubans went into mourning, but younger people were generally indifferent.
articles.lead_paragraph: HAVANA — At the Salon Rojo, one of Havana’s most popular nightspots, where the reggaeton usually blares into the early hours, the music stopped abruptly.
articles.byline: By Damien Cave and Hannah Berkeley Cohen

articles.headline: Miami’s Cuban Exiles Celebrate Castro’s Death
articles.snippet: For many Cuban-Americans, still bitter over the revolution that tore their families from their homes, it was a celebration long in coming.
articles.abstract: For many Cuban-Americans, still bitter over the revolution that tore their families from their homes, it was a celebration long in coming.
articles.lead_paragraph: MIAMI — It did not matter that it was the middle of the night, or that it began to drizzle. When this city’s Cuban-American residents heard the news, they sprinted to Little Havana. They banged pots and pans. They sang the Cuban national anthem and waved the Cuban flag. They danced and hugged, laughed and cried, shouted and rejoiced.

articles.headline: Potential Conflicts Around the Globe for Trump, the Businessman President
articles.snippet: In many of the president-elect’s international development ventures, his business partners have close ties to foreign governments.
articles.abstract: In many of the president-elect’s international development ventures, his business partners have close ties to foreign governments.
articles.lead_paragraph: MANILA — On Thanksgiving Day, a Philippine developer named Jose E. B. Antonio hosted a company anniversary bash at one of Manila’s poshest hotels. He had much to be thankful for.
articles.byline: By Richard C. Paddock, Eric Lipton, Ellen Barry, Rod Nordland, Danny Hakim and Simon Romero

articles.headline: One Family. Six Decades. Myriad Views of Fidel Castro’s Revolution.
articles.snippet: The clash of emotions common in Cuban families is reflected in a grandfather’s loyalty to Mr. Castro and a granddaughter’s glum view of conditions in her country.
articles.abstract: The clash of emotions common in Cuban families is reflected in a grandfather’s loyalty to Mr. Castro and a granddaughter’s glum view of conditions in her country.
articles.lead_paragraph: HAVANA — When Fidel Castro rode victoriously into Havana on Jan. 8, 1959, Juan Montes Torre rushed into the streets to cheer. A poor, uneducated laborer from the eastern countryside of Cuba, he had arrived in the capital a few years earlier and, like most of his neighbors, could hardly believe what was happening.

articles.headline: Trump Claims, With No Evidence, That ‘Millions of People’ Voted Illegally
articles.snippet: The president-elect made the unsubstantiated claim as part of a storm of Twitter posts voicing anger about a three-state recount push.
articles.abstract: The president-elect made the unsubstantiated claim as part of a storm of Twitter posts voicing anger about a three-state recount push.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President-elect Donald J. Trump said on Sunday that he had fallen short in the popular vote in the general election only because millions of people had voted illegally, leveling the baseless claim as part of a daylong storm of Twitter posts voicing anger about a three-state recount push.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: South Korean Leader Digs In Against Rising Calls for Impeachment
articles.snippet: A bizarre scandal and an escalating backlash could make President Park Geun-hye the first South Korean leader to be removed from office since 1979.
articles.abstract: A bizarre scandal and an escalating backlash could make President Park Geun-hye the first South Korean leader to be removed from office since 1979.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — She is facing impeachment and prosecution over allegations of corruption and influence-peddling. One of her advisers is being likened to Rasputin by a shrill South Korean news media. Increasingly large crowds of protesters have taken to the streets, demanding her resignation.

articles.headline: Combative, Populist Steve Bannon Found His Man in Donald Trump
articles.snippet: Mr. Bannon courted politicians who share his dark, populist worldview of a ruling class preying on working Americans and “the Judeo-Christian West” in a “war against Islamic fascism.”
articles.abstract: Mr. Bannon courted politicians who share his dark, populist worldview of a ruling class preying on working Americans and “the Judeo-Christian West” in a “war against Islamic fascism.”
articles.lead_paragraph: When Julia Jones arrived at her office in Santa Monica at 8 a.m. — by Hollywood screenwriter standards, the crack of dawn — she found Stephen K. Bannon already at his desk, which was cluttered with takeout coffees. They were co-writers on a Ronald Reagan documentary, but Mr. Bannon had pretty much taken it over. He had been at work for hours, he told her, writing feverishly about his political hero.

articles.headline: Nintendo’s New Console May Feed Your Nostalgia, if You Can Get One
articles.snippet: The NES Classic Edition, a smaller version of a 30-year-old game system, is one of the year’s hottest gifts. But the trip down memory lane isn’t without headaches.
articles.abstract: The NES Classic Edition, a smaller version of a 30-year-old game system, is one of the year’s hottest gifts. But the trip down memory lane isn’t without headaches.
articles.lead_paragraph: When she heard that Nintendo was planning to reproduce its iconic Nintendo Entertainment System video game console for the holiday season, Emily Bradbury put a note on her calendar and set an alarm on her phone.

articles.headline: In Tougher Fall TV Landscape, New Rules Apply
articles.snippet: Ratings are, once again, down across the board for NBC, ABC, CBS and Fox, but each network can make the claim that it has a new show with a strong pulse.
articles.abstract: Ratings are, once again, down across the board for NBC, ABC, CBS and Fox, but each network can make the claim that it has a new show with a strong pulse.
articles.lead_paragraph: Well, it could be worse.

articles.headline: In Europe, Is Uber a Transportation Service or a Digital Platform?
articles.snippet: The European Court of Justice will hear arguments that will most likely determine how the ride-sharing service can operate across the European Union.
articles.abstract: The European Court of Justice will hear arguments that will most likely determine how the ride-sharing service can operate across the European Union.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ever since Uber showed up in Europe in late 2011, the American ride-booking service has faced vocal opposition.

articles.headline: When A.I. Matures, It May Call Jürgen Schmidhuber ‘Dad’
articles.snippet: A researcher who co-wrote a paper in the 1990s on a crucial artificial intelligence technique feels overlooked by today’s stars in the field.
articles.abstract: A researcher who co-wrote a paper in the 1990s on a crucial artificial intelligence technique feels overlooked by today’s stars in the field.
articles.lead_paragraph: LUGANO, Switzerland — Jürgen Schmidhuber may be the Rodney Dangerfield of artificial intelligence research.

articles.headline: Suspect Is Killed in Attack at Ohio State University That Injured 11
articles.snippet: A man veered his car onto the sidewalk at the campus, leaped out, and stabbed several people with a butcher knife, law enforcement officials said.
articles.abstract: A man veered his car onto the sidewalk at the campus, leaped out, and stabbed several people with a butcher knife, law enforcement officials said.
articles.lead_paragraph: A student at Ohio State University intentionally rammed a car into pedestrians on a busy campus sidewalk on Monday morning and then began slashing passers-by with a butcher knife, the authorities said, injuring 11 students and faculty and staff members, and setting off panic at one of the nation’s largest public universities.
articles.byline: By Mitch Smith, Richard Pérez-Peña and Adam Goldman
